<xs:enumeration value=" Allows the user to select the med░░ines, based on International Nonproprietary Names (INN) or categories of med░░ines. Medicines are classified in three categories Artemisinin derivatives (inc░░ding all the artemisinin derivative monotherapies), Artemisinin based Comb░░ation Therapies (ACTs) and Non-artemisinins. These categories are mutually exc░░sive and individual drugs or combinations are listed below. The selection of all publ░░░tions that contain information on each individual medicine or medicine cate░░ries can be obtained by filtering. "/>

Papers on techniques, drug legi░░ation, reviews, and other reports usually do not contain location information and the░░fore will not appear in the map. They can however be found in the report table. "/>
<xs:enum░░ation value=" Lists the type of sampling methodology used in each report. Only stu░ies with evidence describing how randomisation was performed have been inc░░ded as 'Random Survey' "/>
<xs:enumeration value=" We use, unless otherwise spe░░fied in the report, the term 'falsified' as a synonym for counterfeit or spu░░ous, referring to a medical product produced with criminal intent to mislead, wit░out reference to intellectual property concerns. If authors did not examine pac░░ging we class samples that failed chemical assays, but without detected wrong ac░ive ingredients, as poor quality and not falsified/counterfeit. Samples that did not f░il chemical assays and/or a packaging tests are considered as good quality. Sam░les are only classified as 'Good Quality' if all samples collected were good qua░ity. Samples classified as poor quality, falsified or substandard may con░ain good quality medicines. "/>
<xs:enumeration value=" Lists the type of outlet where the coll░░tion of samples was performed. Reports that do not provide clear information about the d░ug provider will be classified as unknown. "/>

<xs:element name="label">
<xs:simpleType>
<xs:restriction base="xs:string">
<xs:enum░░ation value=" Allows the user to select the medicines, based on International Nonpr░░░ietary Names (INN) or categories of medicines. Medicines are classified in three cate░░ries Artemisinin derivatives (including all the artemisinin derivative monot░░░apies), Artemisinin based Combination Therapies (ACTs) and Non-artemisinins. These cate░░ries are mutually exclusive and individual drugs or combinations are listed below. The sel░░tion of all publications that contain information on each individual med░░ine or medicine categories can be obtained by filtering. "/>
<xs:enumeration value=" Lists the dif░░rent types of publication found describing antimalarial drug quality. Papers on tech░░ques, drug legislation, reviews, and other reports usually do not contain loc░░ion information and therefore will not appear in the map. They can however be found in the re░ort table. "/>
<xs:enumeration value=" Lists the type of sampling methodology used in each re░ort. Only studies with evidence describing how randomisation was per░░rmed have been included as 'Random Survey' "/>
<xs:enumeration value=" We use, unless oth░░wise specified in the report, the term 'falsified' as a synonym for counterfeit or spu░░ous, referring to a medical product produced with criminal intent to mislead, wit░out reference to intellectual property concerns. If authors did not examine pac░░ging we class samples that failed chemical assays, but without detected wrong ac░ive ingredients, as poor quality and not falsified/counterfeit. Samples that did not f░il chemical assays and/or a packaging tests are considered as good quality. Sam░les are only classified as 'Good Quality' if all samples collected were good qua░ity. Samples classified as poor quality, falsified or substandard may con░ain good quality medicines. "/>
<xs:enumeration value=" Lists the type of outlet where the coll░░tion of samples was performed. Reports that do not provide clear information about the d░ug provider will be classified as unknown. "/>
</xs:restriction>
</xs:simpleType>
</xs:ele░ent>
